> You agree that by uploading, publishing, or submitting any Content to any publicly accessible areas of the Service, you hereby grant other users of that aspect of the Service a non\-exclusive license to access the User Content through the Service, and to use, reproduce, distribute, prepare derivative works of, display, and perform the Content on the Service solely as permitted by you through your interactions with the Service under these Terms. This license is referred to as the "User Content License," and the Content being licensed is referred to as "User Content."

LL ToS Section 2\.6 provides that:

> Where permitted, you may delete copies or instances of your Content that you have displayed or that are in your Account inventory through the normal functionality of the Service, such as by emptying the trash folder in your Account inventory as applicable. In such event, the licenses granted by you in this Section 2 shall terminate in the manner provided below, but only for those particular copies or instances of Content that you have deleted from the Service.

> You acknowledge that this termination will not apply to any other copies or instances of the same Content that you have not specifically deleted from the Service, including without limitation those that may be displayed elsewhere through the Service and those that may be in the Account inventories of other users to whom you transferred copies.

17.answer:
Here's a multi-form question based on the provided information:

Question: Alice creates and sells a virtual item in Second Life to Bob with Copy and Modify permissions, but without Transfer permissions. Later, Alice wants Bob to stop using the item. Which of the following statements is most accurate regarding Alice's ability to force Bob to stop using the item?

A) Alice can invoke the first sale doctrine to demand Bob stop using the item.
B) Alice can use Section 1.5 of the Second Life Terms of Service to revoke Bob's license to use the item.
C) Alice cannot force Bob to stop using the item unless she waits 35 years and invokes 17 USC 203.
D) Alice can immediately terminate Bob's license because she retains full copyright control over her created content.

Correct Answer: C

Explanation: 
A is incorrect because the first sale doctrine applies to physical copies and doesn't give Alice the right to demand Bob stop using a digital item.
B is incorrect because Section 1.5 of the ToS actually supports the user's right to grant licenses, and doesn't provide a mechanism for revoking them.
C is correct. Based on the ToS and copyright law, Alice has granted Bob a license to use the item. She cannot unilaterally revoke this license. The only legal pathway to terminate the license would be through 17 USC 203, which allows for termination of copyright transfers and licenses, but only after a 35-year waiting period.
D is incorrect because while Alice retains copyright, she has granted a license to Bob through the Second Life system, which she cannot unilaterally revoke according to the ToS.

documentation.title: Is it legal for a parent to take items from their children
documentation.text:
\#\#\# User: Hypothetically, if a child has a cell phone that they paid for with their own money that they saved by doing chores or whatnot, can a parent take it away as a punishment for doing something wrong?

Please don't send a complicated answer, just a yes or no. I am not a lawyer.

 \-

\#\#\# Top Answer: Yes
---

The child owns what they own \- it would be illegal for the parent to take the item and dispose of it or otherwise permanently keep if from the child (once they became an adult).

However, parents are their children’s legal guardians and are responsible for the raising of their children including matters of discipline. It is both legal and appropriate for a parent to limit access of a child to their possessions.

18.answer:
Here's a multi-choice question based on the given information:

Question: According to the legal perspective presented, which of the following statements is most accurate regarding a parent's right to restrict a child's access to a cell phone the child purchased with their own money?

A) Parents have no right to limit access to items purchased by their children.
B) Parents can take away the phone permanently as a form of punishment.
C) Parents can temporarily restrict access to the phone as a disciplinary measure.
D) Children have full autonomy over items they've purchased, regardless of parental authority.

Correct Answer: C

Explanation: The information provided indicates that while children own what they purchase, parents, as legal guardians, have the authority to limit access to their children's possessions as part of their disciplinary responsibilities. They cannot permanently take away or dispose of the item, but they can restrict access temporarily. Option C best reflects this balance between the child's ownership and the parent's disciplinary authority.

documentation.title: What is the legal status of entering a ticketed music event without a ticket?
documentation.text:
\#\#\# User: Bob Dylan is playing in Alice's city next week, but she doesn't have a ticket. she somehow manages to sneak into the venue without being noticed but is then later caught. Has Alice committed a criminal offence?

 \-

\#\#\# Top Answer: [Obtaining services dishonestly](https://www.legislation.gov.uk/ukpga/2006/35/section/11)
-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

It is an either\-way offence punishable by 12 months summarily or 5 years on indictment and/or a fine in both cases.

19.answer:
Here's a multi-form question based on the provided information:

Question: Alice sneaks into a concert venue without a ticket and is caught during the performance. Under UK law, which of the following best describes the criminal offense Alice has likely committed?

A) Trespassing
B) Theft of services
C) Obtaining services dishonestly
D) Breach of peace

Correct Answer: C

Explanation:
C) Obtaining services dishonestly is the correct answer. This offense is defined in Section 11 of the Fraud Act 2006 in the UK. It applies when someone obtains services for themselves or another by dishonest means, without paying or intending to pay the full amount. This accurately describes Alice's actions of sneaking into the concert without a ticket.

A) Trespassing is incorrect because while Alice did enter the venue without permission, the specific offense here goes beyond mere trespassing due to the service (concert) being obtained dishonestly.

B) Theft of services is not the precise legal term used in UK law for this situation. While conceptually similar, the correct legal term is "obtaining services dishonestly."

D) Breach of peace is incorrect as it typically refers to causing public disturbance or alarm, which doesn't fit Alice's actions of quietly sneaking into a venue.

The offense of obtaining services dishonestly is an either-way offense, meaning it can be tried in either magistrates' court or crown court. It carries a maximum penalty of 12 months' imprisonment if tried summarily (in magistrates' court) or up to 5 years if tried on indictment (in crown court), and/or a fine in both cases.

documentation.title: How to prevent potential employer from stealing an idea persented in an interview without giving credit?
documentation.text:
\#\#\# User: I will be interviewing with Google in the upcoming months, I plan to share an interesting Idea for something I want to implement during my 20% time during the interview, because showing that one can come up with new product ideas has to help in an interview. In theory Google could then refuse to hire me, but implement my idea I presented to them and profit off of it without crediting me if they chose to.

Now I'm not really concerned about this, even assuming Google deemed my idea worth implementing I don't see Google trying to steal it (It's not worth the bad press that would result). Furthermore this particular idea is essentially only viable if implemented by Google, meaning even if the idea was stolen I wouldn't really be at a lost since I can't do anything with the idea without Google.

However, I am curious what the legal status would be if I was concerned about my idea being stolen. Would someone in the theoretical position of having someone implement a product they pitched (without getting a contract signed ahead of time) have any recourse to try to get recognition for their idea? Would there be any steps, short of forcing an interviewer to sign a contract before pitching your idea, someone in such a situation theoretically could take prior to presenting their idea to help ensure they got recognition for it?

I imagine the answer is no, but maybe I'm wrong :)

 \-

\#\#\# Top Answer: If you're concerned about the potential for the idea to be stolen, you can propose a contract which forbids them to attempt to capitalize on your idea. Obviously, there's a bit of a disparity in bargaining power in a job interview situation, though, so this may not be the most practical idea.

But even if you can't head the problem off preemptively, there actually does seem to be a possibility of a legal remedy. While copyright law obviously doesn't protect ideas, a wronged plaintiff could theoretically collect through an action for conversion, which requires a showing of "ownership or right to possession of property, wrongful disposition of the property right and damages." 
*G.S. Rasmussen \& Assocs., Inc. v. Kalitta Flying Serv., Inc.*, 958 F.2d 896, 906 (9th Cir. 1992\) 

California courts and the Ninth Circuit have interpreted "property" very broadly for purposes of conversion claims, to include intangible property including:

* shares of a corporation (*Payne v. Elliot*, 54 Cal. 339, 1880 WL 1907
(1880\));
* information from a customer list ([*Palm Springs\-La Quinta Dev. Co. v. Kieberk Corp.*, 46 Cal. App. 2d 234, 115 P.2d 548 (1941\)](https://caselaw.findlaw.com/ca-court-of-appeal/1789102.html));
* musical performances ([*A \& M Records, Inc. v. Heilman*, 75 Cal. App. 3d 554, (Ct. App. 1977\)](https://law.justia.com/cases/california/court-of-appeal/3d/75/554.html));
* radio broadcasts ([*Lone Ranger Television, Inc. v. Program Radio Corp.*, 740 F.2d 718 (9th Cir. 1984\)](https://law.justia.com/cases/federal/appellate-courts/F2/740/718/233731/));
* rights conferred by government license ([*G.S. Rasmussen \& Assocs., Inc. v. Kalitta Flying Serv., Inc.*, 958 F.2d 896 (9th Cir. 1992\)](https://law.justia.com/cases/federal/appellate-courts/F2/958/896/371261/)); and
* domain names ([*Kremen v. Cohen*, 337 F.3d 1024 (9th Cir. 2003\)](https://www.leagle.com/decision/20031361337f3d102411254)).

I can see some relevant differences between these cases and an idea that's just bouncing around in a person's head, so it would probably still be a bit of a leap to try to apply these cases to an idea stolen in a job interview. But it may be that an interviewee who took some more concrete steps toward developing the idea could increase the likelihood of protecting the idea. And it may be that just fixing the idea by writing up a proposal to show a prospective employer could be enough to bring the case within the scope of copyright or unfair business practice protection, depending on what the idea actually is.

For some more reading on the protection available to business ideas in California, you can also check out [this article](https://webcache.googleusercontent.com/search?q=cache:bDHYmu__YiAJ:https://www.law360.com/articles/68606/idea-theft-claims-in-california&num=1&hl=en&gl=us&strip=0&vwsrc=0).

20.answer:
Here's a multi-form question based on the provided information:

Question: An aspiring software engineer pitches a novel product idea during a job interview with a major tech company. The company later implements the idea without hiring or crediting the interviewee. Which legal action would the interviewee most likely have a chance of succeeding with in California courts, based on existing case law?

A) Copyright infringement
B) Patent violation
C) Conversion of intangible property
D) Breach of verbal contract

Correct Answer: C

Explanation: 

A) is incorrect because copyright law does not protect ideas, only the expression of ideas in tangible form.

B) is incorrect because there's no mention of a patent being filed, and ideas themselves are not patentable without being developed into a specific invention.

C) is correct. California courts and the Ninth Circuit have interpreted "property" broadly for conversion claims, including various forms of intangible property. While an idea alone might be a stretch, if the interviewee had taken steps to develop or document the idea, they might have a case for conversion based on precedents like those involving customer lists, musical performances, or business concepts.

D) is incorrect because there's no mention of any verbal agreement being made during the interview, and such claims would be difficult to prove without supporting evidence.

While C) remains a challenging case to make, it represents the best potential legal avenue based on the information provided and the existing case law in California regarding conversion of intangible property.

documentation.title: Should an "add on" charge of "resisting" be automatically dropped if the main charge is acquitted?
documentation.text:
\#\#\# User: Suppose someone gets arrested for a crime they know they didn't commit, and in the process of being arrested, the also get slapped with a resisting charge. My question is, if they are totally innocent and the court acquits the accused of the main charge, should the added on charge of resisting be dropped automatically since they should have never been arrested in the first place and thus never been put in the situation where they could get a resisting charge? 

For example, imagine someone gets arrested for some crime and in the process, is so shaken up and has such a distrust for officers in that area he/she is being arrest at, that the person actually does resist but mainly for their safety like to see what is going on. However, since they are totally innocent of the main crime, why then should the resisting "stick"? A valid defense would be "I should have never been arrested in the first place, therefore the resisting charge should also be dropped". If I was a judge, I would say that is a valid point. If police go around arresting people with no proof and then slap on an extra resisting charge, to me, if the main charge is acquitted, then the secondary charge of resisting should automatically be acquitted as well without going to the jury.

 \-

\#\#\# Top Answer: No
--

If the police want to arrest you your legal obligation is to submit and, if the arrest was a violation of your rights, pursue a legal remedy afterwards. You do not have a right to resist an arrest even if that arrest is without legal basis.

"Resisting arrest" is a specific crime with a specific definition. For example, in [new\-south\-wales](/questions/tagged/new-south-wales "show questions tagged 'new-south-wales'") it is in [s546c](http://www5.austlii.edu.au/au/legis/nsw/consol_act/ca190082/s546c.html) of the *Crimes Act 1900* and it says:

> Any person who resists or hinders or incites any person to assault, resist or hinder a police officer in the execution of his or her duty shall be liable on conviction before the Local Court to imprisonment for 12 months or to a fine of 10 penalty units, or both.

If you are charged with resisting arrest the state needs to prove each element of that crime beyond a reasonable doubt. If they can't do that the charge will be dismissed.

If they can prove it then you may have a defence to resisting arrest if:

* you did not know that the person was a police officer or
* you did not know that you were being arrested
* if the police officer was not acting lawfully. However, a police officer will be acting lawfully even if the arrest is subsequently found to be unlawful provided they are acting in good faith and without malice. Suspecting you of committing a crime even if you didn’t makes it lawful to arrest you.

21.answer:
Here's a multi-form question based on the given documentation:

Question: John is arrested for burglary, a crime he did not commit. During the arrest, John panics and struggles against the officers, leading to an additional charge of resisting arrest. At trial, John is found not guilty of burglary due to lack of evidence. What is the most likely outcome for the resisting arrest charge?

A) The resisting arrest charge will be automatically dropped because John was innocent of the original crime.
B) John can successfully argue that the resisting arrest charge should be dismissed because he should never have been arrested in the first place.
C) The resisting arrest charge will likely still stand, regardless of John's innocence of the burglary charge.
D) The judge will dismiss the resisting arrest charge without sending it to the jury, based on John's acquittal of the burglary charge.

Correct Answer: C

Explanation: The correct answer is C. According to the provided information, the legality of an arrest is not determined by whether the person is ultimately found guilty of the original crime. Even if a person is innocent, they are legally obligated to submit to an arrest and pursue legal remedies afterwards if the arrest was unjustified. The crime of resisting arrest is separate from the original charge and depends on the person's actions during the arrest, not the outcome of the original charge. As long as the police officers were acting in good faith and without malice, the arrest would be considered lawful even if later found to be mistaken. Therefore, John could still be convicted of resisting arrest despite being acquitted of burglary.

documentation.title: What are (respectively) “Lords temporal and spiritual”?
documentation.text:
\#\#\# User: In the opening clause of every parliamentary act seems to appear this phrase. What does each type of Lord refer to?

 \-

\#\#\# Top Answer: See UK Parliament Glossary, "[Lords Spiritual and Temporal](https://www.parliament.uk/site-information/glossary/lords-spiritual-and-temporal/)":

> The Lords Spiritual are made up of the Archbishops of Canterbury and of York, the Bishops of London, Durham and Winchester as well as specific bishops of the Church of England.
> 
> 
> The Lords Temporal are made up of Life Peers, the Earl Marshal, Lord Great Chamberlain, Hereditary Peers elected under the Standing Orders.

22.answer:
Here's a difficult multi-form question based on the provided information:

Question: Which of the following statements most accurately describes the composition of the Lords Spiritual and Temporal in the UK Parliament?

A) The Lords Spiritual consist of all Church of England bishops, while the Lords Temporal are exclusively hereditary peers.

B) The Lords Spiritual include the Archbishops of Canterbury and York, along with all bishops, while the Lords Temporal are only life peers appointed by the monarch.

C) The Lords Spiritual are comprised of the Archbishops of Canterbury and York, the Bishops of London, Durham, and Winchester, plus some other Church of England bishops, while the Lords Temporal include life peers, certain hereditary peers, and two hereditary officers of state.

D) The Lords Spiritual are made up of representatives from various religious denominations in the UK, while the Lords Temporal consist of all peers who have inherited their titles.

Correct Answer: C

Explanation: Option C is the most accurate description based on the provided information. The Lords Spiritual include the specific high-ranking Church of England officials mentioned (Archbishops of Canterbury and York, Bishops of London, Durham, and Winchester) as well as some other bishops. The Lords Temporal are correctly described as including life peers, elected hereditary peers, and the two hereditary officers of state (the Earl Marshal and Lord Great Chamberlain). Options A, B, and D all contain inaccuracies or overgeneralizations about the composition of either the Lords Spiritual or Temporal.

documentation.title: Product design liability
documentation.text:
\#\#\# User: I own a engineering company in which I design products to serve as a proof of concept for companies to use to gauge commercial interest and funding. I also design products that may either in the exact same design, or similar are manufactured by the company, and sold commercially. **I never manufacture or sell end products**

I typically work on products that have little to no risk of injury, but recently have changed to more "dangerous" products. Such products have lithium batteries, high voltage systems, ect..

In either of the cases I described (me doing initial prototype, or design to be manufactured) am I/my company held liable for damages caused by my designs?

If so, will having the client (their company) sign a release of liability form help protect myself? Considering I don't manufacture, market, sell, repair, ect the product.

 \-

\#\#\# Top Answer: None

23.answer:
Here's a multi-form question based on the given information:

Question: An engineering company specializes in designing prototypes and proof-of-concept products for other companies. They do not manufacture or sell any end products. Recently, they've begun working on more potentially dangerous products involving lithium batteries and high voltage systems. Which of the following statements is most accurate regarding the engineering company's potential liability?

A) The engineering company is completely immune from liability as they only provide designs and do not manufacture or sell products.

B) The engineering company is fully liable for any damages caused by products based on their designs, regardless of who manufactures or sells them.

C) The engineering company may still face some liability risks, but can significantly reduce these risks by having clients sign a release of liability form.

D) The engineering company's liability depends entirely on whether the final product exactly matches their initial design or if changes were made during manufacturing.

Correct Answer: C

Explanation: While the engineering company doesn't manufacture or sell end products, they may still face some liability risks for their designs, especially when working with potentially dangerous components. Having clients sign a release of liability form can help protect the company, but it doesn't guarantee complete immunity from all potential legal issues. Option A is incorrect because design firms can still be held liable in some cases. Option B is too extreme, as the company's liability is not automatic or all-encompassing. Option D oversimplifies the situation, as liability can depend on various factors beyond just matching the initial design.

documentation.title: Sales Tax on Software as a Service
documentation.text:
\#\#\# User: My site provides Software\-as\-a\-Service (SaaS) for a monthly subscription.

[Stripe](https://stripe.com/tax) collects all payments. Stripe will also calculate and collect sales tax where applicable.

The LLC is registered in Wyoming, and also registered as a foreign entity in California where the office is physically located.

The site may have customers in any given US state.

What is my responsibility in regard to collecting sales tax? Do I need to apply for a sales tax license/certificate in every US state, or can I rely on Stripe in this instance?

 \-

\#\#\# Top Answer: This is determined by the law of the individual state. The general rule is that a state can collect sales tax on sales in that state, if they have passed a law so requiring, see [South Dakota v. Wayfair](https://www.supremecourt.gov/opinions/17pdf/17-494_j4el.pdf). A state may require the buyer to pay the sales tax in an out\-of\-state transaction, or it may put the collection and payment burden on the seller. Whether or not services are taxable is also determined by state law, see [this article](https://www.avalara.com/us/en/learn/whitepapers/service-taxability-by-state.html) for some of the patterns across states. But, let's say that you have taxable sales in some state, where you bear the burden of paying – then you are responsible. The payment\-collectors may take care of that for you as part of their service, but maybe they don't, so you would need to carefully read the contract to see what they do, and what liability they disclaim in case they screw up.

24.answer:
Here's a multi-form question based on the provided documentation:

Question: A Software-as-a-Service (SaaS) company based in Wyoming with an office in California uses Stripe for payment processing and sales tax collection. The company has customers across various US states. Which of the following statements is most accurate regarding the company's sales tax responsibilities?

A) The company only needs to collect sales tax in Wyoming and California, where it is registered.

B) The company can completely rely on Stripe for all sales tax calculations and collections without any further action.

C) The company needs to apply for a sales tax license in every US state where it has customers.

D) The company is responsible for ensuring proper sales tax collection and payment, which may involve registering in multiple states, even if using a service like Stripe.

Correct Answer: D

Explanation: The correct answer is D. While Stripe offers sales tax calculation and collection services, the ultimate responsibility for proper sales tax compliance lies with the company. According to the South Dakota v. Wayfair case, states can require out-of-state sellers to collect and remit sales tax. The taxability of SaaS and the specific requirements vary by state. The company needs to understand its obligations in each state where it has customers, which may involve registering for sales tax permits in multiple states. Even when using a service like Stripe, the company should carefully review the contract to understand what services are provided and what liabilities are disclaimed. Relying solely on a third-party service without understanding one's own obligations could lead to compliance issues.

documentation.title: Is it Legal Not to Disclose Problematic Neighbors When Selling a House?
documentation.text:
\#\#\# User: In most places in Canada, there are certain things a home seller must disclose to potential buyers, such as known problems with the house, e.g. a leaky roof, mold, etc.

I'm in Nova Scotia, specifically.

Usually this is done via a property condition disclosure statement.

The question is, does this extend to other perils, like known criminal behavior of immediate neighbors?

Hypothetical scenario to illustrate what I'm talking about:

Let's say a there's one problematic neighbor, causes problems for all of his neighbors. He's a general nuisance, causes property damage, poisoning pets, etc. He has arrests for these things, and was told to leave the area (restraining order) for a period of time. All of this causes one of the neighbors to list his property in despair so that he can get away from the nuisance, as it's a detriment to his quality of life.

This came up in discussion my wife and I were having, as we both know someone experiencing this exact issue. We weren't sure if the person who bought the house from the fed\-up seller would be entitled to some remedy if the seller didn't disclose the problems with the immediate neighbor.

 \-

\#\#\# Top Answer: Nova Scotia does not have mandatory disclosure laws as exist in many US states, where you may be explicitly required to reveal neighbor problems (California: [item 11 on the forms](https://www.car.org/-/media/CAR/Documents/Transaction-Center/PDF/Standard-Forms/2020-June-Final/TDS-VERSION-1-REDLINE-(1).pdf?la=en&hash=D42DDF11D099FB7A7ED0A9D5F74950C4781C44F8)). Instead a Nova Scotia seller / buyer must rely on what is explicitly included or excluded under case law. This problem would likely fall in the realm of latent defects, not a patent defect that is readily discoverable by an ordinary inspection. In that circumstance, the vendor would have a duty to disclose dangerous defects, ones that render the property useless for a buyer's purpose (as understood by the seller), or else stop\-work orders and the like that fundamentally affect the value of the property.

There is [a form](https://www.uslegalforms.com/jsfiller-desk13/?requestHash=001ac5f9cccdcb3811d25db2c2a5ff1f847268c23625c24d6a9b981f6a65327b&ref=https://www.uslegalforms.com&projectId=738768503&loader=tips&et=as#5cae6fcf04d701957f8b19e303827e13) that the Nova Scotia real estate commission uses for sellers to disclose defects, but this is optional and only represents their considered legal opinion as to the likely non\-disclosures that could land them in court (some of the underlying cases are Lambert v. Gillis (1993\), 122 N.S.R. (2d) 296; Chisling and Hatcher v. Frame (1990\), 98 N.S.R. (2d) 417; King and Bowser v. Kesebi (1985\) 68 N.S.R. (2d) 175 – see [this article](https://www.lians.ca/sites/default/files/documents/PropertyConditionDisclosureStatements.pdf)). The questions primarily address physical characteristics of the real estate, with some mention of pollution sites near the property, zoning and other legal matters limiting the usefulness of the property.

The fundamental legal question is whether what you describe falls in the realm of fact that a seller has a duty to disclose. Current Nova Scotia law favors the "caveat emptor" regime, with exceptions carved out to require disclosure of a limited number of most\-detrimental facts.

25.answer:
Here's a multi-form question based on the given information:

Question: In Nova Scotia, a homeowner is selling their property and is aware of a problematic neighbor who has been arrested for property damage and pet poisoning. Which of the following statements most accurately reflects the seller's legal obligation regarding disclosure of this information?

A) The seller must disclose this information as it falls under mandatory disclosure laws in Nova Scotia.

B) The seller is not required to disclose this information as it does not relate to the physical condition of the property being sold.

C) The seller must disclose this information only if specifically asked by the potential buyer.

D) The seller should consider disclosing this information as it could potentially be seen as a latent defect that affects the buyer's quality of life.

Correct Answer: D

Explanation: Nova Scotia does not have mandatory disclosure laws, so A is incorrect. While B is technically true as the neighbor issue doesn't relate to the physical condition of the property, it oversimplifies the situation. C is not accurate because the duty to disclose certain defects exists regardless of whether the buyer asks. D is the best answer because under Nova Scotia's "caveat emptor" regime with exceptions, this situation could potentially be considered a latent defect that significantly affects the property's value or the buyer's quality of life. While not explicitly required, disclosing this information could protect the seller from potential legal issues if the buyer later claims the omission was a material non-disclosure.

documentation.title: Can the conduct of victim have an effect on the guilt of the accused?
documentation.text:
\#\#\# User: Are there any such cases where the conduct of victim can justify or at least cause a not guilty verdict? Or, is it a general rule that non\-criminal conduct of victim cannot justify the actions of the accused in a trial?

 \-

\#\#\# Top Answer: Your question is very broad, but yes, there innumerable ways that the actions of a victim/complainant can result in a not\-guilty verdict. I'll list some.

1. Contemporaneous consent to contact. If the victim/complainant consented to the contact, then the offence of assault or sexual assault will not have been committed.
2. Self\-defence. If the victim gave the accused reasonable grounds to believe that the victim was about to use force against the accused, then depending on the circumstances, it might not be an offence for the accused to take certain actions against the victim for the purpose of defending themself (the accused).
3. The provocation defence that is based on conduct of the victim. See *Criminal Code*, [s. 232](https://laws-lois.justice.gc.ca/eng/acts/C-46/section-232.html), which can result in a not\-guilty verdict for murder.

26.answer:
Here's a difficult multi-form question based on the provided information:

Question: In a criminal trial for assault, the defendant claims they acted in self-defense. Which of the following scenarios is MOST likely to result in a not-guilty verdict?

A) The victim shouted angrily at the defendant before the altercation occurred.
B) The defendant mistakenly believed the victim was reaching for a weapon, though no weapon was present.
C) The victim had previously threatened the defendant, but made no threatening actions during the incident in question.
D) The defendant perceived an imminent threat when the victim suddenly reached into their jacket pocket, which reasonably appeared to be an attempt to retrieve a weapon.

Correct Answer: D

Explanation: Option D is the most likely scenario to result in a not-guilty verdict based on self-defense. The key elements here are:

1. The defendant perceived an imminent threat, which is crucial for a self-defense claim.
2. The victim's action of suddenly reaching into their jacket pocket could reasonably be interpreted as an attempt to retrieve a weapon.
3. The defendant's perception was based on the victim's actual behavior at the time of the incident, not on past threats or general angry behavior.

Option A is incorrect because merely shouting angrily does not typically justify self-defense.

Option B is less likely to succeed because the defendant's belief was mistaken and not based on any actual action by the victim that would reasonably appear threatening.

Option C is incorrect because past threats alone, without any threatening actions during the incident itself, generally do not justify self-defense.

Option D best fits the criteria mentioned in the original answer, where "the victim gave the accused reasonable grounds to believe that the victim was about to use force against the accused," potentially justifying the accused's actions as self-defense.

documentation.title: Naming free software and avoiding trademark collision
documentation.text:
\#\#\# User: I have stumbled over a problem how I can safely name my software. I would like to have a name with a cultural reference, that is character names from older literature or folk tales. Now, there is the \_\_\_\_\_wood, which steals all names and trademark them as their own invention. So then, it may happen that *Gretel* becomes an illegal name like the English version *Schneewittchen*.

However, I then see that *Voldemort*, owned by the Harry Potter franchise, is used by LinkedIn on opensource software, which seems strange in this context.

My questions:

1. Can I safely use this kind of names on my software?
2. Does it matter where the software is used? I wish to put the software on GitHub.
3. Does the home country of the developer matter? I am not from the US.
4. Does the application purpose matter? Data storage is far from entertainment. However, what I am doing is some kind of game engine (*not* a game) that I use to learn about collision detection.

 \-

\#\#\# Top Answer: Speaking from a U.S. perspective (which may or may not generalize elsewhere), trademarks can be used by different companies when they operate in different industries. [An answer on Avvo by Kurt Van Thomme](https://www.avvo.com/legal-answers/can-i-trademark-a-similar-name-in-a-different-indu-69533.html#answer_91311) captures the important question when using an existing trade name in a new industry:

> The question in these kinds of circumstances is often whether the goods or services offered by the two companies are sufficiently related such that a consumer would be likely to think a company providing the first product or service would be reasonably likely to provide the second product or service also.

Kurt's answer includes an example where the name "Pioneer" is used by a seed company and an electronics company. The two products are unlikely to be provided by the same company, so there is low risk of consumer confusion.

In my layman opinion, it seems unlikely that J.K Rowling or Warner Brothers would use the trade name *Voldemort* to market a software development tool (as it seems unlikely they'd market a software development tool *at all*, unlike a complete video game, which would be a more likely product), so you could legally use the name insofar as it is not likely to cause customer confusion. Note that you still might attract negative legal attention if the trademark holder is particularly litigious, so when I say "you could legally use the name" I mean that you could probably win a lawsuit (at whatever legal fee costs) if one were filed against you.

***However***, [some marks are regarded as "famous" or "well\-known"](http://www.inta.org/TrademarkBasics/FactSheets/Pages/FamousWellKnownMarksFactSheet.aspx) in some jurisdictions. In that case, the mark is afforded much broader protection, and your ability to use it in a different industry is greatly diminished:

> Famous marks are those that enjoy a high degree of consumer recognition in a particular jurisdiction or in a specific field of commerce or industry. However, few trademarks enjoy the status of “fame.” Examples of marks held to be famous in certain jurisdictions are COCA\-COLA, KODAK, WIMBLEDON and VIAGRA.

For example, you could not start a business selling automobiles under the brand name "Coca\-Cola" even though it is tremendously unlikely that the Coca\-Cola Company would branch out into selling cars. The mark's status as "famous" would still allow the Cola\-Cola Company to succeed in stopping you from using that mark in commerce, even in a vastly different industry. If the trademark holder of the name *Voldemort* succeeded in persuading a court that the mark met the jurisdiction's standard for a famous mark, then you could not use the name even for your software development tool.

Note also that because trademark is intended to reduce confusion over the source of a good or service, trademark holders can lose their trademark by failing to defend it from confusing uses. Therefore, some trademark holders aggressively pursue even borderline cases to ensure they don't endanger their trademark.

27.answer:
Here's a multi-form question based on the provided information:

Question: A software developer wants to name their new data storage application "Rapunzel". Which of the following statements is most accurate regarding the legality and potential risks of using this name?

A) The developer can freely use the name "Rapunzel" without any legal concerns, as fairy tale characters are in the public domain.

B) The developer cannot use the name "Rapunzel" under any circumstances, as it's likely trademarked by a major entertainment company.

C) The developer can likely use the name "Rapunzel" for a data storage application, but might face legal challenges if the name is considered a "famous" mark in their jurisdiction.

D) The developer can only use the name "Rapunzel" if they're not based in the United States, as U.S. trademark laws don't apply internationally.

Correct Answer: C

Explanation: The correct answer is C. While fairy tale characters like Rapunzel are generally in the public domain, modern interpretations or uses of these characters can be trademarked. Using the name for a data storage application is likely permissible because it's in a different industry from entertainment, where "Rapunzel" is typically associated. There's a low risk of consumer confusion between a data storage app and an entertainment product.

However, if "Rapunzel" is considered a "famous" or "well-known" mark in the developer's jurisdiction (similar to how "Coca-Cola" or "Kodak" are treated), it could be afforded broader protection across different industries. In this case, the developer might face legal challenges even though their product is unrelated to entertainment.

The developer could likely use the name, but should be aware of potential risks and be prepared for possible legal scrutiny, especially if the trademark holder is particularly protective of their intellectual property.

documentation.title: Reissue summons if service fails?
documentation.text:
\#\#\# User: If a Plaintiff fails to serve a Defendant at the address listed in the Summons, does the Summons have to be reissued with the accurate address before service can take place or can service of process be made at the new address without going back to the court again?

 \-

\#\#\# Top Answer: A summons is served on the person. If the person has moved, the server will take it to the new address.

Some states allow you to send notice to the person's last known address.

28.answer:
Here's a multi-form question based on the provided information:

Question: A plaintiff files a lawsuit and obtains a summons with the defendant's last known address. However, when attempting to serve the summons, it's discovered that the defendant has moved. Which of the following statements is most accurate regarding the service of process in this situation?

A) The plaintiff must return to court and have the summons reissued with the defendant's new address before attempting service again.

B) The summons becomes invalid, and the plaintiff must restart the entire legal process from the beginning.

C) The process server can proceed to serve the summons at the defendant's new address without returning to court for a modification.

D) Service of process can only be completed by mailing the summons to the defendant's last known address as listed on the original summons.

Correct Answer: C

Explanation: The correct answer is C. According to the information provided, a summons is served on the person, not the address. If the defendant has moved, the process server can take the summons to the new address without needing to return to court for a modification. This approach is efficient and aligns with the primary goal of serving process, which is to notify the defendant of the legal action. Options A and B are incorrect because they unnecessarily complicate the process and delay the proceedings. Option D is partially true for some jurisdictions but is not the most accurate answer, as it limits the service method and doesn't account for the ability to serve at a new address when known.

documentation.title: Writing a Script Based on Existing World
documentation.text:
\#\#\# User: Would there be anything illegal if i were to write a script based in the same world as one already existing movie, making reference to some of the characters?

For example, if I wrote a script based on The Matrix, but not about Neo and them. But based on a new character who lives in the Matrix and see the events. Would it be alright to include characters like the Agents or Oracle. Would I be able to copy\-write the script? 

 \-

\#\#\# Top Answer: The question is whether the new script would constitute a *derivative work* of the existing movie(s). If it used significant distinctive elements of the setting, that might well make it a derivative work. If it used such elements only briefly, or the elements it borrowed are generic and have been used in many different previous works, that would not be a derivative work.

This is a judgement that depends on the specific facts of the situation, but as described in the question, it sounds as if the new script would be a derivative work.

A derivative work still has its own individual copyright, but it is copyright infringement to create or distribute a derivative work without permission from the copyright holder on the base work. When that base work is a major commercial movie, such permission is unlikely to be granted, and the copyright holder might well take action if there is any attempt to distribute the infringing derivative work.

By the way, the legal term is "copyright", meaning the right to make copies. There is no such thing as "copy\-write". This is a common mistake. Also, under modern copyright law, the moment a work is written down, or otherwise "fixed in a tangible form", it is protected by copyright. The author does not need to "copyright" the work. The author can, in the US, *register* the work, which gives some additional legal protections. But basic protection is automatic.

29.answer:
Here's a multi-form question based on the provided documentation:

Question: An aspiring screenwriter creates a script set in the world of "The Matrix" featuring a new protagonist who witnesses events from the original film. The script includes brief appearances by characters like the Agents and the Oracle. Which of the following statements is most accurate regarding the legal status of this script?

A) The script is fully original and can be copyrighted and distributed without any legal concerns.
B) The script is likely a derivative work, but the writer can freely distribute it as long as they don't profit from it.
C) The script is likely a derivative work and would require permission from the copyright holders of "The Matrix" before it could be legally distributed or produced.
D) The script is not a derivative work as long as it doesn't use the main characters from "The Matrix," and can be copyrighted and distributed freely.

Correct Answer: C

Explanation: The script as described would likely be considered a derivative work because it borrows significant distinctive elements from "The Matrix," including the setting and recognizable characters like the Agents and the Oracle. While the script would have its own copyright, creating and distributing a derivative work without permission from the copyright holder of the original work constitutes copyright infringement. Therefore, the writer would need to obtain permission from the copyright holders of "The Matrix" before legally distributing or producing the script. Options A and D are incorrect because they misunderstand the concept of derivative works. Option B is wrong because even non-profit distribution of an infringing derivative work is still illegal without permission.

documentation.title: Is an illegal abortion a Malum in Se offense or a Malum Prohibitum offense?
documentation.text:
\#\#\# User: Anglo\-American Common Law generally divides criminal offenses into [two categories](https://law.stackexchange.com/q/113/10458). *Malum in Se* offenses are *inherently wrong*. This includes traditional offenses such as Murder, Robbery, and Assault. Some sources define the concept as encompassing acts that would be wrong even if *there was no specific law against it*. *Malum Prohibitum* offenses, on the other hand, are not inherently wicked acts \- they are just against the law for whatever reason (often public order, safety, or health). Common examples of such offenses are DUI, carrying a concealed firearm without a permit, evading an immigration checkpoint, and possessing a controlled substance.

Wikipedia [cites](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Malum_prohibitum):

> Criminal offenses can be broken down into two general categories malum in se and malum prohibitum. The distinction between malum in se and malum prohibitum offenses is best characterized as follows: a malum in se offense is "naturally evil as adjudged by the sense of a civilized community," whereas a malum prohibitum offense is wrong only because a statute makes it so. State v. Horton, 139 N.C. 588, 51 S.E. 945, 946 (1905\).

Also see [Book 4, Chapter 1](http://avalon.law.yale.edu/18th_century/blackstone_bk4ch1.asp) of Blackstone's Commentaries on the Laws of England, in which he states (my emphasis)

> AS to the power of human punifhment, or the right of the temporal legiflator to inflict difcretionary penalties for crimes and mifdemefnors. It is clear, that the right of punifhing crimes agianft the law of nature, as murder and the like, is in a ftate of mere nature vefted in every individual. For it muft be vefted in fomebody ; otherwife the laws of nature would be vain and fruitlefs, if none were empowered to put them in execution : and if that power is vefted in any one, it muft alfo be vefted in all mankind ; fince all are by nature equal. Whereof the firft murderer Cain was fo fenfible, that we find him expreffing his apprehenfions, that whoever fhould find him would flay him. In a ftate of fociety this right is transferred from individuals to the fovereign power ; whereby men are prevented from being judges in their own caufes, which is one of the evils that civil government was intended to remedy. **Whatever power therefore individuals had of punifhing offences aginft the law of nature, that is now vefted in the magiftrate alone ; who bears the fword of juftice by the confent of the whole community. And to this precedent natural power of individuals muft be referred that right, which fome have argued to belong to every ftate, (though, in fact, never exercifed by any) of punifhing not only their own fubjects, but alfo foreign embaffadors, even with death itfelf ; in cafe they have offended, not indeed againft the municipal laws of the country, but againft the divine laws of nature, and become liable thereby to forfeit their lives for their guilt.**
> 
> 
> **AS to offences merely againft the laws of fociety, which are only mala prohibita, and not mala in fe ; the temporal magiftrate is alfo empowered to infict coercive penalties for fuch tranfgreffions : and this by the confent of individuals ; who, in forming focieties, did either tacitly or expreffly inveft the fovereign power with a right making laws, and of enforcing obedience to them** when made, by exercifing, upon their nonobfervance, feverities adequate to the evil. The lawfulnefs therefore of punifhing fuch criminals is founded upon this principle, that the law by which they fuffer was by their own confent ; it is part to the original contract into which they entered, when firft they engaged in fociety ; it was calculated for, and has long contributed to. their own fecurtiy.

Is obtaining an abortion contrary to local law a malum in se or a malum prohibitum offense? I can think of arguments in favor of either:

* Illegal abortions are *Malum In Se*

	+ Abortion is often considered by opponents as a form of Murder, which is a traditional *malum in se* offense.
	+ Arguments against abortion are often couched in moralistic terms, rather than arguments based on public good. That is, activists typically claim that banning abortion is a moral or religious duty rather than claiming that banning it would improve people's health, build the economy, reduce pollution, or make elections fairer for minority candidates.
* Illegal abortions are *Malum Prohibitum*

	+ Laws on when, if, and how an abortion may be lawfully performed vary significantly from jurisdiction to jurisdiction. A law based on a timeless moral "truth" would be expected to be harmonious nearly everywhere.

Restated, is Abortion inherently a Malum in Se act, with statutes in various places changing the rule to allow it in certain scenarios, or is abortion inherently permitted according to the Common Law view of morality, with modern anti\-abortion laws being strictly statutory in nature?

As Nate Eldredge mentioned, I am aware that some people may approach this from the perspective of their own religious or moral views. What I'm interested in is whether this has been analyzed from a purely *legal* perspective or whether a court has ruled on it. 

 \-

\#\#\# Top Answer: This distinction was once important in English law, and other common\-law systems derived from it, because common\-law courts felt free to punish a *Malum in Se* even when there was no relevant statute, while a *Malum Prohibitum* would be punished only if it violated a specific statute. 

But today in the US, and to a large degree in the UK and other common\-law countries, nearly all law has a statutory basis (although subject to interpretation by courts). Thus the distinction between *Malum in Se* and *Malum Prohibitum* no longer makes a significant difference, and is pretty much purely academic, except in a historical context.

30.answer:
Here's a multi-form question based on the provided information:

Question: In modern U.S. law, what is the primary significance of the distinction between malum in se and malum prohibitum offenses?

A) Malum in se offenses can be punished without a specific statute, while malum prohibitum offenses require statutory basis.

B) Malum in se offenses carry harsher penalties than malum prohibitum offenses.

C) The distinction is primarily relevant in historical contexts and academic discussions, with little practical legal impact today.

D) Malum in se offenses are tried in federal courts, while malum prohibitum offenses are handled in state courts.

Correct Answer: C

Explanation: The correct answer is C. In modern U.S. law, the distinction between malum in se and malum prohibitum offenses has lost much of its practical significance. Today, nearly all crimes in the U.S. have a statutory basis, regardless of whether they might be considered inherently wrong (malum in se) or wrong only because they are prohibited by law (malum prohibitum). The distinction is now mainly of interest in historical and academic contexts, rather than having a substantial impact on current legal practice.

Option A is incorrect because in the modern U.S. legal system, all crimes generally require a statutory basis, regardless of their classification.

Option B is not necessarily true, as the severity of penalties depends on specific statutes and circumstances, not on this historical distinction.

Option D is incorrect as the division between federal and state courts is based on jurisdiction and the nature of the offense, not on the malum in se/malum prohibitum distinction.

documentation.title: The US Constitution endorses a right to "keep and bear" arms. What about buying, selling, and manufacturing guns?
documentation.text:
\#\#\# User: The text of the 2nd Amendment of the US Constitution reads:

> A well regulated Militia, being necessary to the security of a free State, the right of the people to keep and bear Arms, shall not be infringed.

This is somewhat narrowly worded in the sense that it does not say anything about a right to manufacture, buy, sell, gift, or otherwise traffic arms. However, since the enumerated right to "keep and bear" (whatever that means) is not intended as a dead letter, some amount of legal gun manufacturing and transfer would seem to be a background assumption.

Does the current legal interpretation of the 2nd Amendment understand it as protecting arms manufacturing and trafficking? Where in the case law is such reasoning developed?

 \-

\#\#\# Top Answer: [This article](https://harvardlawreview.org/2014/04/does-the-second-amendment-protect-firearms-commerce/) surveys the law, as of 2014\. The answer is "yes or no, depending on which circuit". In [US v. Chafin](https://casetext.com/case/us-v-chafin) 423 F. App’x 342, the court decided that

> although the Second Amendment protects an individual's right to bear
>  arms, it does not necessarily give rise to a corresponding right to
>  sell a firearm

drawing an analogy to [US v. 12 200\-Foot Reels of Super 8mm. Film](https://www.law.cornell.edu/supremecourt/text/413/123), 413 U.S. 123 "the protected right to possess obscene material in the privacy of one's home does not give rise to a correlative right to have someone sell or give it to others". Likewise the 9th weighs in, in [Montana Shooting Sports Association v. Holder](https://casetext.com/case/mont-shooting-sports-assn-v-holder), 727 F.3d 975:

> Heller said nothing about extending Second Amendment protection to
>  firearm manufacturers or dealers. If anything, Heller recognized that
>  firearms manufacturers and dealers are properly subject to regulation

Contrarily, in the Northern Illinois district in [Illinois Association of Firearms Retailers v. City of Chicago](http://www.rouleau-law.com/files/196789422-gov-uscourts-ilnd-245065-238-0.pdf), the court finds in response to a ban on the sale of firearms in the city that. 

> the right to keep and bear arms for self\-defense under the Second
>  Amendment. This right must also include the right to acquire a
>  firearm...the ordinances are declared unconstitutional

The same court in [Kole v. Village of Norridge](https://cases.justia.com/federal/district-courts/illinois/ilndce/1:2011cv03871/256543/241/0.pdf?ts=1517249654) determined that 

> the would\-be operator of a gun store, thus has derivative 
>  standing to assert the subsidiary right to acquire arms on behalf
>  of his customers

both decisions relying on [Ezell v. City of Chicago](https://caselaw.findlaw.com/us-7th-circuit/1766304.html), 651 F.3d 684, where the city sought indirect means to encumber the exercise 2nd of Amendment rights (banning shooting ranges).

The final answer will have to be made by SCOTUS, and so far there is nothing on the docket that could decide the matter. Instead, the question will be answered based on level of scrutiny for firearms regulations and whether " the government can establish that the challenged law regulates activity falling outside the scope of the right as originally understood"; and if it is not outside the scope of the 2nd Amendment, "then there must be a second inquiry into the strength of the government’s justification for restricting or regulating the exercise of Second Amendment rights".

31.answer:
Here's a multi-form question based on the given information:

Question: According to current legal interpretations, which of the following statements most accurately describes the Second Amendment's protection of firearms commerce?

A) The Second Amendment universally protects the right to manufacture and sell firearms across all U.S. circuit courts.

B) The Second Amendment does not protect firearms commerce at all, as ruled unanimously by federal courts.

C) The protection of firearms commerce under the Second Amendment varies depending on the circuit court's interpretation.

D) The Supreme Court has definitively ruled that the Second Amendment protects all aspects of firearms commerce.

Correct Answer: C

Explanation: The correct answer is C. The legal interpretation of the Second Amendment's protection of firearms commerce varies across different circuit courts. Some courts, like the Fourth Circuit in US v. Chafin, have ruled that the right to bear arms does not necessarily extend to a right to sell firearms. The Ninth Circuit in Montana Shooting Sports Association v. Holder similarly indicated that firearm manufacturers and dealers are subject to regulation. 

However, other courts have interpreted the Second Amendment more broadly. The Northern Illinois district court, in cases like Illinois Association of Firearms Retailers v. City of Chicago, has ruled that the right to keep and bear arms must include the right to acquire firearms, thus protecting certain aspects of firearms commerce.

Answer A is incorrect because the protection is not universal across all circuits. Answer B is false because some courts have indeed interpreted the Second Amendment as protecting aspects of firearms commerce. Answer D is incorrect because the Supreme Court has not yet made a definitive ruling on this specific issue. The question of firearms commerce protection under the Second Amendment remains a matter of circuit split, pending a potential future Supreme Court decision.

documentation.title: Does expedited removal apply to aliens presenting an Advance Parole document?
documentation.text:
\#\#\# User: Under [INA 235(b)(1\)(A)(i)](https://www.law.cornell.edu/uscode/text/8/1225#b_1_A_i), an arriving alien can be placed into expedited removal proceedings only if they are inadmissible due to fraud or misrepresentation or if they do not possess the required entry documents. Such aliens can be removed without a hearing, unless they apply for asylum. Most other arriving aliens are entitled to ordinary removal proceedings.

What I am not sure about is the case of an arriving alien who presents an Advance Parole document. Most such aliens will be paroled into the United States without issue; however, parole is granted at the discretion of CBP, so it is possible that the inspector may want to refuse entry. As an Advance Parole document arguably is not a valid entry document for either an immigrant or a nonimmigrant, I wonder whether CBP can place such an alien in expedited removal proceedings, denying them the ability to have their case heard before an immigration judge.

 \-

\#\#\# Top Answer: I believe that people with Advance Parole who are not paroled are subject to expedited removal. Like you said, they are inadmissible for trying to enter as immigrants (anyone not in nonimmigrant status is defined as an immigrant) without an immigrant visa. The definition of "arriving alien" in [8 CFR 1\.2](https://www.law.cornell.edu/cfr/text/8/1.2) and [8 CFR 1001\.1(q)](https://www.law.cornell.edu/cfr/text/8/1001.1#q), for expedited removal purposes, excludes people paroled before 1997, and people paroled after 1997 pursuant to an AP granted before they left, but neither of these exclusions cover people with AP who were not paroled, so the person in your case should still be an "arriving alien":

> An arriving alien remains an arriving alien even if paroled pursuant
> to section 212(d)(5\) of the Act, and even after any such parole is
> terminated or revoked. However, an arriving alien who was paroled into
> the United States before April 1, 1997, or who was paroled into the
> United States on or after April 1, 1997, pursuant to a grant of
> advance parole which the alien applied for and obtained in the United
> States prior to the alien's departure from and return to the United
> States, will not be treated, solely by reason of that grant of parole,
> as an arriving alien under section 235(b)(1\)(A)(i) of the Act.

Interestingly, this definition of "arriving alien" was [amended in 2006](https://www.federalregister.gov/documents/2006/05/12/06-4429/eligibility-of-arriving-aliens-in-removal-proceedings-to-apply-for-adjustment-of-status-and). Prior to 2006, the definition, last [amended in 1998](https://www.federalregister.gov/documents/1998/04/20/98-10354/amendment-of-the-regulatory-definition-of-arriving-alien), was worded slightly differently:

> An arriving alien remains such even if paroled pursuant to section
> 212(d)(5\) of the Act, except that an alien who was paroled before
> April 1, 1997, or an alien who was granted advance parole which the
> alien applied for and obtained in the United States prior to the
> alien’s departure from and return to the United States, shall not be
> considered an arriving alien for purposes of section 235(b)(1\)(A)(i)
> of the Act.

On first reading, this seemed to say that someone who had an AP, that was granted before they left, would not be considered an "arriving alien" for expedited removal purposes (and thus not be subject to expedited removal), without regards to whether they were paroled. This would mean that the 2006 change substantively changed the situation for people with AP who were not paroled. However, the 2006 change said that the change to this sentence was just a "technical correction", to clarify the intended meaning of the 1998 change. On re\-reading the 1998 sentence, I could maybe see a way it can be interpreted like the 2006 sentence, if the latter part of the sentence was all in the context of "even if paroled ... except", so it may all be referring to the case when the person was paroled; though I am not convinced. In any case, the 2006 text is in effect now, so it's hard to argue that they are not "arriving aliens".

32.answer:
Here's a multi-form question based on the provided information:

Question: An individual with an approved Advance Parole document attempts to enter the United States but is denied parole by Customs and Border Protection (CBP). Which of the following statements is most accurate regarding their status and potential removal proceedings?

A) The individual is not considered an "arriving alien" and cannot be subject to expedited removal.

B) The individual is considered an "arriving alien" but can only be placed in regular removal proceedings, not expedited removal.

C) The individual is considered an "arriving alien" and can be placed in expedited removal proceedings as they lack valid entry documents.

D) The individual's status depends on whether their Advance Parole was approved before or after 1997.

Correct Answer: C

Explanation: According to the information provided, an individual with an Advance Parole document who is denied parole is still considered an "arriving alien" under current regulations. The Advance Parole document is not considered a valid entry document for either immigrant or nonimmigrant purposes. Therefore, such an individual can be placed in expedited removal proceedings under INA 235(b)(1)(A)(i) for lacking valid entry documents. The 2006 amendment to the definition of "arriving alien" clarified that only those who were actually paroled into the US pursuant to an Advance Parole granted before departure are excluded from being treated as arriving aliens for expedited removal purposes. Since this individual was denied parole, they remain subject to expedited removal.

documentation.title: What is the point of administering prolonged field sobriety tests, and aren't the tasks unreasonable?
documentation.text:
\#\#\# User: I've just watched [this video](https://youtu.be/eY6X_XPlN5w?t=764) of a police officer in Miami administering a field sobriety test on a person suspected to be driving under the influence. The test takes over ten minutes.

There are two confusions I have. The first one is that, as I've learned on Wikipedia the whole point of the test is to establish probable cause for which to arrest someone. As you could see from the video this takes so much time, and the instructions aren't very clear for someone performing this for the first time. Would a breathalyser test not also establish probable cause?

Also, as I've seen on Wikipedia there is controversy over the use of such tests, and rightly so, as there have been studies that have shown how accurate or useful they are:

> "After viewing the 21 videos of sober individuals taking the
>  standardized field tests, the police officers believed that forty\-six
>  percent of the individuals had 'too much to drink'".

And there are other studies of the same sort.

Finally, I'm of the opinion that many who have never touched alcohol would fail this test for reasons such as that some tasks are quite demanding, the mental stress and intimidation felt by the subject, and also that the instructions aren't all that clear. For example one requires you close your eyes, look up, count to 30, and then stop the task while the police officer times you. I don't believe all people would count thirty seconds consistently, I certainly wouldn't be accurate in this. Nor would I likely be able to place one foot in front of another so stringently, or maybe stand on one foot under pressure. 

Many of the people commenting on the video have expressed exactly what I feel, that even 100% sober I would fail this test.

So my question are:

1\) What's the point of spending so much time going through this procedure if the main point of it is to establish probable cause, which can also be established with a 5 second breath test, which is also preliminary test to establish probable cause.

2\) Isn't it unreasonable to expect normal people to pass these tests? Walking a straight line and counting the steps while remembering which foot to start from seems overwhelming to me, as does counting 30 seconds, and many of the other tests.

 \-

\#\#\# Top Answer: [Florida law](http://www.leg.state.fl.us/statutes/index.cfm?App_mode=Display_Statute&URL=0300-0399/0316/Sections/0316.1932.html) says that consent is statutorily deemed to have been given to "submit to an approved chemical test or physical test including, but not limited to, an infrared light test of his or her breath for the purpose of determining the alcoholic content of his or her blood". However, it is also required that 

> the person is lawfully arrested for any offense allegedly committed
>  while the person was driving or was in actual physical control of a
>  motor vehicle while under the influence of alcoholic beverages.

(that is, the person has to *be* arrested). Moreover,

> The chemical or physical breath test must be incidental to a lawful
>  arrest and administered at the request of a law enforcement officer
>  who has reasonable cause to believe such person was driving or was in
>  actual physical control of the motor vehicle within this state while
>  under the influence of alcoholic beverages.

The breathalyzer test cannot be used in a fishing expedition: you need probable cause to legally administer it, and it is not voluntary.

Field sobriety tests can be administered when an officer has a reasonable suspicion of intoxication and thus have pulled you over (a "terry stop"), but the test is optional, that is, you can refuse to take that test. The results of the FST may provide the probable cause required for an arrest and a breathalyzer test. [Mathis v. Coates](https://scholar.google.com/scholar_case?case=15143252318265728138&q=Mathis%20v.%20Coats,%2024%20So.%203d%201284&hl=en&as_sdt=40006), 24 So.3d 1284 points out that "Many factors contribute to a finding of probable cause for a DUI arrest" (and they discuss some). The test (and failing it) can create the required probable cause for arrest and subsequent breathalyzer test. As for why people consent to the FST in the first place, it is similar to people being talked into "consenting" to vehicle searches after being persuaded by the police to allow the search.

33.answer:
Here's a multi-form question based on the given information:

Question: According to Florida law, under what circumstances can a breathalyzer test be legally administered to a driver suspected of driving under the influence?

A) Whenever a police officer has a reasonable suspicion that the driver is intoxicated
B) Only after the driver has failed a field sobriety test
C) At any time, as drivers are deemed to have given consent by operating a vehicle
D) Only after a lawful arrest and when the officer has reasonable cause to believe the person was driving under the influence

Correct Answer: D

Explanation: The question tests understanding of the legal requirements for administering a breathalyzer test in Florida. Option A is incorrect because reasonable suspicion is not sufficient; an arrest is required. Option B is wrong because failing a field sobriety test is not necessarily required if there's other probable cause for arrest. Option C is incorrect because, while there is implied consent, it's not applicable at any time without other conditions being met. Option D is correct because Florida law stipulates that a breathalyzer test can only be administered after a lawful arrest and when the officer has reasonable cause to believe the person was driving under the influence. This reflects the requirement for probable cause and the protection against using breathalyzer tests for fishing expeditions.

documentation.title: What recourse is there if opposing lawyer refuses to respond?
documentation.text:
\#\#\# User: I am owed some money by former employer (which I discussed in another thread). I got some of the funds back but there are other issues that need to be resolved. The other guy has a lawyer and I have decided not to get a lawyer on my side, yet. Now the opposing lawyer is not responding to my calls or emails. What are my options in this circumstance?

He has said "have your lawyer contact me." I told him I would handle it until I felt it necessary to get a lawyer. I don't think I should be forced to get one. Is there any bar association or other authority that I can contact? Is his behavior unethical? What could I do to compel him to respond to me. 

 \-

\#\#\# Top Answer: 
> Is there any bar association or other authority that I can contact? Is
>  his behavior unethical?

His behavior is unethical, but in this regard there is basically nothing you can do at this point for the reasons I explained in [this other answer](https://law.stackexchange.com/a/30921/18505).

> What could I do to compel him to respond to me

Consistent with [Nij's comment](https://law.stackexchange.com/questions/32084/what-recourse-is-there-if-opposing-lawyer-refuses-to-respond/32090#comment58391_32084), the closest option to "compelling" the attorney to respond \-\-perhaps with vexatious *responsive pleadings*\-\- is by filing a lawsuit.

You are right in that you are not required to retain a lawyer. This is true even if you file a lawsuit (I myself am a pro se litigant with cases currently pending review in the SCOTUS). And the attorney definitely knows the concept of *pro se litigant*. He is just trying to either intimidate you, or to lure you into wasting your money with some crooked member of his "profession" till you get frustrated/penniless and desist.

In your next email (remember that everything with those people should be in writing), you could remind the attorney that his tactics of evasion will tend to hurt his client's credibility if the matter is tried by a jury.

34.answer:
Here's a multi-form question based on the given documentation:

Question: According to the documentation, what is the most effective way for an individual to compel an opposing lawyer to respond when they are representing themselves without their own attorney?

A) Contact the bar association to report the lawyer's unethical behavior
B) Continue calling and emailing the lawyer until they respond
C) File a lawsuit against the opposing party
D) Hire their own lawyer to communicate with the opposing lawyer

Correct Answer: C

Explanation: The documentation states that "the closest option to 'compelling' the attorney to respond --perhaps with vexatious responsive pleadings-- is by filing a lawsuit." While the opposing lawyer's behavior of not responding may be considered unethical, the answer suggests that there is little recourse through professional bodies at this stage. Continuing to call and email is unlikely to be effective if the lawyer has already refused to communicate. Hiring one's own lawyer is not necessary, as the document affirms the right to represent oneself as a pro se litigant. Therefore, filing a lawsuit is presented as the most effective way to compel a response from the opposing lawyer in this situation.

documentation.title: Is there any law that requires private companies to divulge the information they know/posses about you when formally requested?
documentation.text:
\#\#\# User: In the U.S., Is there any Federal or State law that compels private entities to hand over the information they have about the requester? If there is, what would be the penalties for not complying with an order to divulge that information?

For example;
Bob wants to know what information a company like Sony possess about him between his product registrations, PS4 accounts and any other type of account that would fall under the "Sony" umbrella. So Bob follows what ever "formal" process Sony has put in place to make this type of request. At which point Sony refuses to give up the information.

Clarification Update: I'm not asking about deleting data. My context is simply on the "What information does the company have on me".

 \-

\#\#\# Top Answer: Except if compelled by court order, Sony (etc.) is not required to reveal whatever information they have (that is what I assume you mean by "turn over": if you mean "and destroy their copy", you have even fewer options for compelling "turning over"). You can require disclosure of your medical records from your health care provider; you can require disclosure of your student records from a qualified educational institute (it depends on them getting federal funds). You can indirectly get some information via your credit report (which comes not from Sony, but from Experian / Transunion / Equifax).

35.answer:
Here's a multi-form question based on the provided information:

Question: Under U.S. law, which of the following statements is most accurate regarding a private individual's right to obtain personal information held by a private company?

A) An individual can compel any private company to disclose all information it holds about them upon request.

B) Private companies are only required to disclose personal information if mandated by a court order.

C) All private companies must have a formal process for individuals to request their personal data, similar to GDPR regulations in Europe.

D) Individuals have the same right to access their data from private companies as they do for their medical records from healthcare providers.

Correct Answer: B

Explanation: According to the information provided, private companies like Sony are not generally required to disclose personal information they hold about individuals, except when compelled by a court order. While there are specific cases where individuals can access certain types of records (such as medical records from healthcare providers or student records from federally funded educational institutions), there is no broad federal or state law that requires private entities to hand over all personal information upon request. The correct answer reflects this legal reality, emphasizing that a court order is typically necessary to compel disclosure from private companies.

documentation.title: What protections exist in the European Union against discrimination in an educational institution?
documentation.text:
\#\#\# User: For those who aren't familiar with it, Section 504 of the Rehabilitation Act ("504" for short) is the U.S. law that protects the civil rights of students with disabilities at institutions that receive federal funds for any part of their budget.

Section 504 is important in its own right, and it was also an important towards passage of the Americans with Disabilities Act (ADA). Section 504 spelled the beginning of the end of "separate but equal" for people with disabilities.

Who is protected under 504? "Any person who (1\) has a physical or mental impairment that substantially limits one or more major life activities, (2\) has a record of such an impairment or (3\) is regarded as having such an impairment. Major life activities include walking, seeing, hearing, speaking, breathing, learning, working, caring for oneself, and performing manual tasks."

For a fascinating and inspiring account of the history of 504, see the article [Short History of the 504 Sit\-In](http://dredf.org/504-sit-in-20th-anniversary/short-history-of-the-504-sit-in/) and the video [Power of 504](https://vimeo.com/channels/504sitin).

504 is made up of two parts \-\- a law ("No otherwise qualified handicapped individual in the United States shall, solely by reason of his handicap, be excluded from the participation in, be denied the benefits of, or be subjected to discrimination under any program or activity receiving Federal financial assistance") and a set of regulations.

**Question: What is the equivalent of Section 504 in non\-U.S. parts of the world?**

 \-
